Situation1: They join in when the family talks about possible weekend plans.
Expectation2: Perform maintenance and cleaning of the machines to ensure optimal performance
Situation2: Routine servicing is scheduled next week during a planned shutdown.
Story:
I sat at the dinner table, half-listening as my family tossed around ideas for our weekend together. My younger brother wanted to go hiking, my parents suggested a movie night, and my sister was already planning a picnic menu. They all looked at me, waiting for my input, expecting me to be there, to laugh and share in the plans. I wanted to say yes, to be the sister who never missed a family moment.

But in the back of my mind, I couldn’t stop thinking about the machines at work. The scheduled shutdown was next week, and I was responsible for the maintenance—cleaning, checking every part, making sure nothing would break down when production resumed. My supervisor had reminded me how crucial this was, how any delay could cost the company thousands. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing on me: my family’s hope for togetherness and my duty to keep the machines running smoothly. My heart tugged in two directions as everyone waited for my answer, and I sat there, caught between being a good sister and a reliable machine repairer.
